summary: Build a browser-based baby monitor that works as a single HTML file, enabling peer-to-peer video streaming between devices on the same local network with cry detection notifications. Parents can use any two devices with browsers as a zero-cost baby monitor without installing apps or setting up servers, with a working prototype delivered in 1 day.

assumptions.text: Both devices must be on the same local WiFi network for WebRTC connection to succeed, as STUN/TURN servers are out of scope
Users are comfortable manually copying and pasting connection codes between devices to establish the peer connection
Higher false positive rate for cry detection is acceptable to ensure we don't miss actual crying (prioritizing sensitivity over precision)
Users will keep the browser open (though tab can be backgrounded) for monitoring to work - closing the browser stops all monitoring
One-to-one connection model is sufficient (one camera device streaming to one viewer device at a time)

requirementsInterpreted.text: The entire application must be delivered as a single HTML file under 5MB with all JavaScript, CSS, and assets embedded inline
Users establish connection by manually exchanging WebRTC SDP offer/answer codes between sender and viewer devices
Video and audio stream from the camera device to the viewer device with less than 3 seconds latency on local network
Cry detection runs on both sender and viewer sides using client-side audio analysis, triggering browser notifications on the viewer even when the tab is backgrounded
Users can toggle the same application instance between sender mode (camera) and viewer mode (monitor) without reloading
When WebRTC connection fails due to NAT/firewall, display clear error explaining the limitation and suggest connecting both devices to the same WiFi network
Application must work completely offline after the initial HTML file is loaded, with no external CDN or API dependencies

outOfScope.text: Cloud recording, storage, or historical playback of monitoring sessions
STUN/TURN server infrastructure for NAT traversal - connections only work on same local network
User authentication, accounts, or multi-user access control
Mobile native apps or mobile-optimized responsive design
Production-grade cry detection algorithm with machine learning optimization
Multi-room monitoring with multiple simultaneous camera sources

riskFlags.text: 1-day timeline severely limits testing, polish, and edge case handling - this is explicitly a rapid prototype to demonstrate feasibility
WebRTC connections will fail when devices are on different networks or behind restrictive firewalls - users must connect to same WiFi
Manual SDP code exchange is error-prone and not user-friendly, but necessary without signaling server infrastructure
Cry detection algorithm will be basic prototype-level without ML, tested only against publicly available audio samples
